<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 124, 87]]<|/det|>
## Data  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 102, 675, 560]]<|/det|>
speed of light in free space, \(c = 3.00\times 10^{8}\mathrm{ms}^{- 1}\) permeability of free space, \(\mu_{0} = 4\pi \times 10^{- 7}\mathrm{Hm}^{- 1}\) permittivity of free space, \(\epsilon_{0} = 8.85\times 10^{- 12}\mathrm{Fm}^{- 1}\) \((\frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}} = 8.99\times 10^{9}\mathrm{mF}^{- 1})\) elementary charge, \(e = 1.60\times 10^{- 19}\mathrm{C}\) the Planck constant, \(h = 6.63\times 10^{- 34}\mathrm{Js}\) unified atomic mass constant, \(u = 1.66\times 10^{- 27}\mathrm{kg}\) rest mass of electron, \(m_{\mathrm{e}} = 9.11\times 10^{- 31}\mathrm{kg}\) rest mass of proton, \(m_{\mathrm{p}} = 1.67\times 10^{- 27}\mathrm{kg}\) molar gas constant, \(R = 8.31\mathrm{JK}^{- 1}\mathrm{mol}^{- 1}\) the Avogadro constant, \(N_{\mathrm{A}} = 6.02\times 10^{23}\mathrm{mol}^{- 1}\) the Boltzmann constant, \(k = 1.38\times 10^{- 23}\mathrm{JK}^{- 1}\) gravitational constant, \(G = 6.67\times 10^{- 11}\mathrm{Nm}^{2}\mathrm{kg}^{- 2}\) acceleration of free fall, \(g = 9.81\mathrm{ms}^{- 2}\)

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 106, 555, 142]]<|/det|>
\[s = ut + \frac{1}{2} at^{2}\] \[\nu^{2} = u^{2} + 2as\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 160, 521, 176]]<|/det|>
\[W = p\Delta V\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 190, 531, 220]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 230, 515, 246]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 258, 570, 290]]<|/det|>
\[p = \frac{1}{3}\frac{Nm}{V} < c^2 >\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 295, 533, 312]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 328, 600, 345]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 346, 604, 365]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 377, 531, 410]]<|/det|>
\[V = \frac{Q}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}r}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[426, 430, 620, 448]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 467, 590, 485]]<|/det|>
\[C = C_{1} + C_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 500, 522, 522]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 537, 590, 555]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[426, 572, 620, 590]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 607, 555, 624]]<|/det|>
\[x = x_{0}\sin \omega t\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 641, 580, 659]]<|/det|>
\[x = x_{0}\exp (-\lambda t)\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 675, 530, 707]]<|/det|>
\[\lambda = \frac{0.693}{t_1}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[299, 73, 700, 90]]<|/det|>
<pre>Answer **all** the questions in the spaces provided.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 104, 96, 122]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 104, 146, 122]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 104, 875, 136]]<|/det|>
The drag force \(D\) on an object of cross-sectional area \(A\), moving with a speed \(v\) through a fluid of density \(\rho\), is given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 144, 556, 173]]<|/det|>
\[D = \frac{1}{2} C\rho A\nu^2\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 182, 343, 198]]<|/det|>
where \(C\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 212, 361, 228]]<|/det|>
Show that \(C\) has no unit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[845, 339, 875, 357]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 370, 148, 388]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 370, 772, 387]]<|/det|>
A raindrop falls vertically from rest. Assume that air resistance is negligible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 401, 180, 419]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 401, 875, 433]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 1.1, sketch a graph to show the variation with time \(t\) of the velocity \(v\) of the raindrop for the first 1.0s of the motion.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[170, 447, 780, 654]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[443, 675, 509, 692]]<|/det|>
<pre>Fig. 1.1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[846, 692, 876, 710]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 723, 181, 742]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 723, 660, 740]]<|/det|>
Calculate the velocity of the raindrop after falling 1000m.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[504, 868, 875, 885]]<|/det|>
<form>velocity = ............................................... m s\(^{-1}\) [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 75, 146, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 73, 875, 107]]<|/det|>
In practice, air resistance on raindrops is not negligible because there is a drag force. This drag force is given by the expression in (a).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 78, 944, 120]]<|/det|>
<form>Examiner's Use</form>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 120, 180, 138]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 120, 875, 152]]<|/det|>
State an equation relating the forces acting on the raindrop when it is falling at terminal velocity.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[848, 183, 876, 201]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 212, 178, 230]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 212, 875, 260]]<|/det|>
The raindrop has mass \(1.4 \times 10^{- 5} \text{kg}\) and cross-sectional area \(7.1 \times 10^{- 6} \text{m}^2\). The density of the air is \(1.2 \text{kg} \text{m}^{- 3}\) and the initial velocity of the raindrop is zero. The value of \(C\) is 0.60.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 274, 734, 291]]<|/det|>
1. Show that the terminal velocity of the raindrop is about \(7 \text{m} \text{s}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[848, 402, 876, 420]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 432, 875, 479]]<|/det|>
<pre>2. The raindrop reaches terminal velocity after falling approximately \(10 \text{m}\). On Fig. 1.1, sketch the variation with time \(t\) of velocity \(v\) for the raindrop. The sketch should include the first \(5 \text{s}\) of the motion.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[848, 481, 876, 498]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 95, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 875, 107]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 756, 875, 790]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 875, 108]]<|/det|>
A nuclear reaction between two helium nuclei produces a second isotope of helium, two protons and 13.8 MeV of energy. The reaction is represented by the following equation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[897, 78, 944, 120]]<|/det|>
<form>For Examiner's Use</FORM>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[265, 128, 687, 157]]<|/det|>
\[_{2}^{3}\mathrm{He} + _{2}^{3}\mathrm{He}\rightarrow \dots \dots \dots \mathrm{He} + 2\dots \dots \mathrm{p} + 13.8\mathrm{MeV}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 167, 146, 185]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 167, 418, 185]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[848, 167, 876, 185]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 198, 148, 217]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 198, 728, 217]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 322, 146, 341]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 322, 670, 341]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 504, 534, 523]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 537, 205, 556]]<|/det|>
<pre>State

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 570, 180, 588]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 570, 606, 588]]<|/det|>
a possible type of radiation that may be produced,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[848, 600, 876, 618]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 630, 181, 649]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 630, 845, 649]]<|/det|>
why the energy of this radiation is less than the 13.8 MeV given in the equation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[848, 661, 876, 679]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 693, 148, 712]]<|/det|>
